title: Test-Driven Development [TDD]
text:
Step 1: Write a Test (Red Phase)

Identify a small, testable unit of functionality.
Write a test that asserts the expected behavior.
Run the test (it should fail since the implementation doesn‚Äôt exist yet).


import pytest

def test_addition():
    assert add(2, 3) == 5  # Function doesn't exist yet

title: Test-Driven Development [TDD]
section: Step 2: Write Minimal Code to Pass the Test (Green Phase)
text:
Step 2: Write Minimal Code to Pass the Test (Green Phase)

Implement only the necessary code to make the test pass.


def add(a, b):
    return a + b


Run the test again (it should pass now).

title: Test-Driven Development [TDD]
text:
Step 3: Refactor the Code (Refactor Phase)

Clean up the implementation without changing behavior.
Ensure all tests still pass after refactoring.


def add(a: int, b: int) -> int:
    return a + b  # Adding types

title: Taming Your Terminal: Dotfiles & GNU Stow
text:
What are dotfiles?

Configuration files that live in your $HOME directory
Usually start with a dot (so they‚Äôre ‚Äúhidden‚Äù):

.bashrc, .zshrc
.gitconfig
.config/ghostty/config

They control how your tools behave:

shell prompt, aliases, colors
git defaults, editor settings, etc.
crumbs: Taming Your Terminal: Dotfiles & GNU Stow

title: Taming Your Terminal: Dotfiles & GNU Stow
text:
Why care about dotfiles?

New machine? ‚Üí ‚ÄúWhy doesn‚Äôt anything feel right?‚Äù
Dotfiles in a repo give you:

reproducible setups
easy sharing of configuration (new laptop, new team member)
a place to grow your personal setup over time
crumbs: Taming Your Terminal: Dotfiles & GNU Stow

title: Taming Your Terminal: Dotfiles & GNU Stow
text:
Dotfiles as a developer‚Äôs fingerprint

Everyone‚Äôs environment is a bit different:

preferred shell, editor, prompt, tools

Your dotfiles encode:

how you navigate
how you debug
how you use git, ssh, etc.

Putting them in a repo:

documents how you work
lets you borrow good ideas from others üòÑ
crumbs: Taming Your Terminal: Dotfiles & GNU Stow

title: Taming Your Terminal: Dotfiles & GNU Stow
text:
The problem: dotfiles sprawl

Config files live all over $HOME:

~/.bashrc
~/.gitconfig
~/.config/ghostty/config

If you edit them in-place:

hard to sync between machines
easy to accidentally diverge

We‚Äôd like a single source of truth in a repo, and a clean way to ‚Äúdeploy‚Äù them into $HOME.
crumbs: Taming Your Terminal: Dotfiles & GNU Stow

title: Taming Your Terminal: Dotfiles & GNU Stow
text:
GNU Stow
GNU Stow is a symlink manager.

You keep ‚Äúreal‚Äù files in a repo like:

~/dotfiles/
  bash/.bashrc
  bash/.aliases
  git/.gitconfig
  ghostty/.config/ghostty/config

Then you ‚Äústow‚Äù them into $HOME:

cd ~/dotfiles
stow -t "$HOME" bash git ghostty

stow creates symlinks:

~/.bashrc  -> ~/dotfiles/bash/.bashrc
~/.gitconfig -> ~/dotfiles/git/.gitconfig
crumbs: Taming Your Terminal: Dotfiles & GNU Stow

title: Taming Your Terminal: Dotfiles & GNU Stow
section: Why Stow is nice for dotfiles
text:
Why Stow is nice for dotfiles

Keeps $HOME clean ‚Üí just symlinks
Easy to enable/disable groups:

stow -t "$HOME" bash
stow -D -t "$HOME" bash   # unstow

Encourages a modular layout:

one folder per ‚Äúpackage‚Äù (bash, git, ghostty, ‚Ä¶)

Works great with git:

version control your dotfiles repo
clone + stow on any machine
crumbs: Taming Your Terminal: Dotfiles & GNU Stow

title: Python Testing 101: Writing Your First Unit Tests
text:
What is a Unit Test?

A unit test checks that a small unit of code works as expected.
Usually a single function or method.
Helps you catch bugs early, refactor confidently, and build better software.
crumbs: Python Testing 101: Writing Your First Unit Tests

title: Python Testing 101: Writing Your First Unit Tests
text:
Why Should Data Scientists Care?

Prevent breaking your analysis pipeline accidentally.
Add guardrails for complex logic (e.g., custom transforms).
Make code easier to reuse and maintain.

title: Python Testing 101: Writing Your First Unit Tests
text:
Unit Testing Workflow

Write failing test -> Run with pytest (It should fail)
Write just enough code to pass -> Re-run pytest
See it pass üéâ
Refactor code if needed
Repeat üîÅ

title: Python Testing 101: Writing Your First Unit Tests
text:
Best Practices

üß™ Test one case per test, keep them small!
üîÅ Test edge cases and common use
üßº Use clear naming: test_functionname_case
üì¶ Structure code so logic is in testable functions (not in notebooks!)
crumbs: Python Testing 101: Writing Your First Unit Tests

title: Python Testing 101: Writing Your First Unit Tests
text:
Code Structure for Testing
Before testing: - Your code should live in a .py file, e.g.¬†my_module.py - Tests should go in a separate file: test_my_module.py
project/
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ my_module.py
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ test_my_module.py

title: Python Testing 101: Writing Your First Unit Tests
text:
Let‚Äôs Write a Failing Test
test_my_module.py:
from my_module import multiply_by_two

def test_multiply_by_two():
    assert multiply_by_two(3) == 6
crumbs: Python Testing 101: Writing Your First Unit Tests

title: Python Testing 101: Writing Your First Unit Tests
text:
Run it with pytest
pytest
Expect output like:
>       assert multiply_by_two(3) == 6
E       NameError: name 'multiply_by_two' is not defined
‚¨ÜÔ∏è Good! The test is failing as expected.
crumbs: Python Testing 101: Writing Your First Unit Tests

title: Python Testing 101: Writing Your First Unit Tests
section: Write Just Enough Code to Pass
text:
Write Just Enough Code to Pass
my_module.py:
def multiply_by_two(x):
    return x * 2
Re-run pytest:
collected 1 item
test_my_module.py .                                    [100%]
‚úÖ Green means good!
crumbs: Python Testing 101: Writing Your First Unit Tests

title: Python Testing 101: Writing Your First Unit Tests
text:
Common Anti-Patterns to Avoid
üö´ Too much in one test - Hard to precisely understand what failed and why
üö´ Testing implementation details - Tests should focus on what your function does and outputs, not how it does it
üö´ Skipping tests for ‚Äòjust a script‚Äô - Scripts evolve fast ‚Äî Make testable functions early and part of your default workflow
üö´ Functions that are hard to test - If a function: - Has side effects - Does too many things - Depends on global state
‚û°Ô∏è It might need to be split into smaller pieces
üí° If it‚Äôs hard to write a simple test, your function may need refactoring!
crumbs: Python Testing 101: Writing Your First Unit Tests

title: Python Testing 101: Writing Your First Unit Tests
text:
What‚Äôs Next?

Try testing:

Edge cases (0, negative numbers, empty lists, incorrect input types)
Your own utility functions

Explore:

Test coverage (pytest-cov)
Mocks and temporary files

title: 12 Factor Applications (Pt 1)
text:
Motivation

Developing and Deploying Apps can be difficult
The 12 Factor App methodology provides guidelines that ensure

clarity,
scalability,
maintainability

Benefits both developers and operations teams.

title: 12 Factor Applications (Pt 1)
text:
Why are 12 Factor Apps Important?

Consistency and predictability in application behavior.
Simplifies the development lifecycle.
Eases the process of deploying, scaling, and maintaining applications.
Promotes collaboration between development and operations (DevOps).

title: 12 Factor Applications (Pt 1)
text:
Best Practices
A lot of these concepts are things that are considered best practices, but collected together.

You are probably already do a bunch of these things
You may not know you do it (it just feels right)
You may not know why you do it (it just seems to work)
You may do it because you were told to (it isn‚Äôt broken)

title: 12 Factor Applications (Pt 1)
text:
Benefits for Developers

Clear guidelines for application structure and behavior.
Simplified onboarding and reduced cognitive load.
Easier debugging and local development.
Predictable dependencies and environments.

title: 12 Factor Applications (Pt 1)
text:
Benefits for DevOps/Operations

Streamlined deployment and automated management.
Improved reliability and faster issue resolution.
Easier monitoring and logging.

title: 12 Factor Applications (Pt 1)
text:
The 12 Factors (Brief Overview)

Codebase: One codebase tracked in version control, many deploys.
Dependencies: Explicitly declare and isolate dependencies.
Config: Store configuration in the environment.
Backing Services: Treat backing services as attached resources.
Build, Release, Run: Strictly separate build and run stages.
Processes: Execute the app as one or more stateless processes.

title: 12 Factor Applications (Pt 1)
text:
The 12 Factors (Brief Overview)

Port Binding: Export services via port binding.
Concurrency: Scale out via the process model.
Disposability: Maximize robustness with fast startup and graceful shutdown.
Dev/Prod Parity: Keep development, staging, and production similar.
Logs: Treat logs as event streams.
Admin Processes: Run admin tasks as one-off processes.

title: 12 Factor Applications (Pt 1)
text:
Examples of Common Pitfalls

Configuration hardcoded in source code.
Dependencies not clearly defined or versioned.
Stateful processes causing unpredictable behavior.
Significant differences between development and production environments.

title: 12 Factor Applications (Pt 1)
text:
Getting Started with 12 Factor Apps

Review your current projects against the 12 factors.
Incrementally adopt factors as you enhance or refactor projects.
Foster collaboration and awareness across development and operations teams.

title: Build Systems and Data Pipelines
text:
Build system
A build system is a tool (or library/package) for:

Declaring build ‚Äútargets‚Äù (outputs)
Defining the steps required to create those targets
Executing those steps

it usually also includes a mechanism for caching:

Identifying what the inputs are to a step (i.e.¬†code files)
Determining if the outputs are stale (outdated)
Determining what steps need to be re-run based on staleness

title: Build Systems and Data Pipelines
text:
Data Pipelines
A data pipeline system is a tool (or library/package) for:

Declaring build ‚Äútargets‚Äù (outputs)
Defining the steps required to create those targets
Executing those steps

it usually also includes a mechanism for caching:

Identifying what the inputs are to a step (i.e.¬†data, code files)
Determining if the outputs are stale (outdated)
Determining what steps need to be re-run based on staleness

title: Build Systems and Data Pipelines
text:
Task runner
A task runner is a tool that runs tasks without caching. They may or may not support dependency resolution.
Examples of task runners:

just
npm run
Shell scripts

A build system that ignores its caches can be used as a task runner

text:
Enabling latest
If you treat data and code both as dependencies, you can very easily start to talk about the latest version of a data object (or dataset) in the same way you can talk about the latest version of an app or package

frequently (for us), code is what changes.

Continuous Publication

If everything is a build, then everything can be a deploy
If it can be deployed, it could be deployed to PROD

The CI/CD pipeline is our Continuous Publication mechanism. It is possible to track latest and have up-to-date information, while still checking against tests, model expectations, invariants, and data quality checks.
It is also possible to mark old versions as inaccurate or deprecated

This idea can sound really scary to people. It‚Äôs important to have faith in your automated checks. It‚Äôs also possible to have human-in-the-loop approval steps

section: üèéÔ∏è Will it make the car go faster?
text:
üèéÔ∏è Will it make the car go faster?

Red Bull‚Äôs Formula 1 Racing team asks one question before every decision:

‚ÄúWill it make the car go faster?‚Äù
If the answer is no, it‚Äôs not a priority.

Everyone from the pit crew to the strategist knows the same goal.
For RMI, that question might be more like:

‚ÄúWill it drive decarbonization?‚Äù
This question helps us focus our energy and creativity on work that accelerates impact ‚Äî the equivalent of making our car go faster.

title: OKRs 101
section: üéØ Why are we talking about OKRs?
text:
üéØ Why are we talking about OKRs?
Objectives and Key Results help bridge our day-to-day work with SPD‚Äôs broader mission:

Enabling public and private sector actors to make energy transition decisions using SPD products.
They:

Define what to prioritize and (often more crucially) what not to.

Help every team member align on outcomes that move the needle.

Connect organization, team, and personal objectives to measurable outcomes.

title: OKRs 101
text:
‚öôÔ∏è OKR Fundamentals
Good OKRs always focus on outcomes and not activities.

Objective: What we want to achieve
Key Results: How we‚Äôll measure success
Each KR must be measurable and collectively signal achievement of the Objective.

title: OKRs 101
text:
üß© Anatomy of a Good OKR

Example Objective:

Ensure every SPD product delivers impact and engagement, not just technical completion.

Key Results:

All new project concepts validated with real users (0‚Äì1.0)

All new project proposals budgeted for comms & design (0‚Äì1.0)

All product launches include a ‚Äúsplash‚Äù marketing moment (0‚Äì1.0)

Collaboration process defined with Influence team (0‚Äì1.0)

title: OKRs 101
text:
üßÆ Stretch and Grade
If you always hit 100%, your goals aren‚Äôt ambitious enough.

Key Results shouldn‚Äôt be binary ‚Äúdone/not done.‚Äù

We use a 0‚Äì1.0 scale to track progress.

~0.7 indicates we‚Äôre at the right level of stretch ‚Äî ambitious but achievable.

OKRs are designed to push learning, not punish shortfalls.

title: OKRs 101
text:
‚ö†Ô∏è Common Pitfalls

OKRs should be:

Few in number

Measurable

Focused on value, not activity

Avoid:

Confusing outputs: üö´ ‚Äúdeploy web application to production and publish blog post‚Äù)
with outcomes: ‚úÖ ‚ÄúX% of pilot users log in more than twice within the first month‚Äù)
Setting too many OKRs ‚Äî focus is power

Writing vague or unmeasurable goals (‚Äúdo more research‚Äù)

We decide what‚Äôs most important each quarter

We keep workload realistic to prevent burnout

title: How to Commit Conventionally
text:
Why we‚Äôre here
In this session, we‚Äôll walk through the Conventional Commits spec and why it‚Äôs useful in practice:

clearer PR history
easier changelogs
(optionally) automated version bumps & releases

title: How to Commit Conventionally
text:
Agenda

What do Conventional Commits solve?
The spec (the minimum you need)
‚ÄúBreaking changes‚Äù + SemVer mapping
Common patterns (scopes, footers, PR merges)
Automated tooling
Resources


If your org uses squash merges, you still benefit: PR title becomes the ‚Äúcommit message.‚Äù

title: How to Commit Conventionally
text:
Commit messages drift
Without a shared convention, git history can easily become:

inconsistent (‚ÄúFix stuff‚Äù, ‚Äúupdate‚Äù, ‚ÄúWIP‚Äù)
hard to scan in git log
painful to turn into release notes
ambiguous for reviewers (‚Äúis this a feature or a fix?‚Äù)


Emphasize: you‚Äôre not ‚Äúpolicing,‚Äù you‚Äôre reducing cognitive load for future-you.

title: How to Commit Conventionally
text:
What is Conventional Commits?
A lightweight convention for commit messages that are:

human-readable
machine-parseable

It ‚Äúdovetails with SemVer‚Äù by making it easy to identify:

features
fixes
breaking changes


Point to the spec later; for now focus on the shape and why it matters.

title: How to Commit Conventionally
text:
The core format
<type>[optional scope][optional !]: <description>

[optional body]

[optional footer(s)]
Examples:

feat: add portfolio export to CSV
fix(api): handle empty scenario set
refactor!: drop legacy endpoint

title: How to Commit Conventionally
text:
Types: pick a small set
Common, widely-used types:

feat ‚Äî new user-visible behavior
fix ‚Äî bug fix
docs ‚Äî documentation only
refactor ‚Äî code change, no behavior change (ideally)
test ‚Äî tests only
chore ‚Äî tooling, build, deps, housekeeping
ci ‚Äî CI pipeline changes

title: How to Commit Conventionally
text:
Scope
Scopes are optional, but can help answer ‚Äúwhere‚Äù a change is relevant, especially in larger codebases:
Examples:

feat(ui): add scenario picker
fix(db): prevent deadlock on upsert
docs(api): document auth header

Good scopes are:

small nouns or abbreviations (api, ui, db, auth, deps)
stable over time
not personal (‚Äújackson-fix‚Äù)

title: How to Commit Conventionally
text:
Breaking changes
Using a ‚Äúbang‚Äù (!) in the header indicates a breaking change:

feat!: remove v1 scenario fields

If you need to give more context, you can use a footer in the commit description:
feat!: remove v1 scenario fields

BREAKING CHANGE: v1 fields were removed; migrate to v2 schema

title: How to Commit Conventionally
text:
Conventional Commits -> SemVer
The common automated release mapping goes something like:

fix -> PATCH
feat -> MINOR
! or BREAKING CHANGE -> MAJOR

Other types need to be mapped appropriately. This is still just a convention (not magic) and requires engineers to buy into using the convention consistently.

title: How to Commit Conventionally
text:
Example: a ‚Äúgood‚Äù conventional commit
fix(auth): refresh tokens on 401

Previously, an expired token caused an infinite retry loop.
Now we refresh once and surface an error if it fails.

Refs: STIT-125, #823

title: How to Commit Conventionally
text:
Migrating from ‚Äúmeh‚Äù to ‚Äúconventional‚Äù

Before: ignore stuff
After: chore(git): add build artifacts to .gitignore

title: How to Commit Conventionally
text:
What about Squash merges?
If the repo you are working on uses squash merges the PR title gets squashed into a commit message. Write the PR title as a conventional commit!

e.g.¬†PR title: feat(ui): add scenario picker

title: How to Commit Conventionally
text:
Automated tooling
Conventional Commits are machine-parseable, so automation can reliably:

Validate messages at commit / PR time
‚Üí catches missing type, malformed scope, or unclear descriptions early
Classify changes from history
‚Üí groups commits into Features, Fixes, Docs, Chores, etc.
Generate release notes / changelogs
‚Üí produces consistent summaries straight from merged work
Decide the next version (if you use SemVer)
‚Üí fix ‚Üí patch, feat ‚Üí minor, BREAKING CHANGE / ! ‚Üí major
